metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Now continue working on our new branch in our local Git.
content.html: Now continue working on our new branch in our local Git.

content.text: Lets pull from our GitHub repository again so that our code is up-to-date:
content.html: Lets pull from our GitHub repository again so that our code is up-to-date:

content.code:
git
pull
remote: Enumerating objects: 5, done.
remote: Counting objects: 100% (5/5), done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
remote: Total 3 (delta 2), reused 0 (delta 0), pack-reused 0
Unpacking objects: 100% (3/3), 851 bytes | 9.00 KiB/s, done.
From https://github.com/w3schools-test/hello-world
* [new branch]      html-skeleton -> origin/html-skeleton
Already up to date.
content.code_html:
git pull
remote: Enumerating objects: 5, done.
remote: Counting objects: 100% (5/5), done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
remote: Total 3 (delta 2), reused 0 (delta 0), pack-reused 0
Unpacking objects: 100% (3/3), 851 bytes | 9.00 KiB/s, done.
From https://github.com/w3schools-test/hello-world
 * [new branch]      html-skeleton -> origin/html-skeleton
Already up to date.

content.text: Now our main branch is up todate. And we can see that there is a new branch available on GitHub.
content.html: Now our main branch is up todate. And we can see that there is a new branch available on GitHub.

content.code:
git
status
On branch master
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean
content.code_html:
git status
On branch master
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean

content.text: And confirm which branches we have, and where we are working at the moment:
content.html: And confirm which branches we have, and where we are working at the moment:

content.code_html:
git branch
* master

content.text: So, we do not have the new branch on our local Git. But we know it is available on GitHub. So we can use the -a option to see all local and remote branches:
content.html: So, we do not have the new branch on our local Git. But we know it is available on GitHub. So we can use the -a option to see all local and remote branches:

content.code_html:
git branch -a
* master
  remotes/origin/html-skeleton
  remotes/origin/master

content.text: Note: branch -r is for remote branches only.
content.html: Note: branch -r is for remote branches only.

content.text: We see that the branch html-skeleton is available remotely, but not on our local git. Lets check it out:
content.html: We see that the branch html-skeleton is available remotely, but not on our local git. Lets check it out:

content.code:
git
checkout html-skeleton
Switched to a new branch 'html-skeleton'
Branch 'html-skeleton' set up to track remote branch 'html-skeleton' from 'origin'.
content.code_html:
git checkout html-skeleton
Switched to a new branch 'html-skeleton'
Branch 'html-skeleton' set up to track remote branch 'html-skeleton' from 'origin'.

content.text: And check if it is all up to date:
content.html: And check if it is all up to date:

content.code:
git
pull
Already up to date.
content.code_html:
git pull
Already up to date.

content.text: Which branches do we have now, and where are we working from?
content.html: Which branches do we have now, and where are we working from?

content.code_html:
git branch
* html-skeleton
  master

content.text: Now, open your favourite editor and confirm that the changes from the GitHub branch carried over.
content.html: Now, open your favourite editor and confirm that the changes from the GitHub branch carried over.

content.text: That is how you pull a GitHub branch to your local Git.
content.html: That is how you pull a GitHub branch to your local Git.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which command lists all local and remote branches?
content.html: Which command lists all local and remote branches?

metadata.question: Which command lists all local and remote branches?

content.question: Which command lists all local and remote branches?
